title: Israeli strike kills a senior Hezbollah commander in south Lebanon
message:
The Israeli military said it had struck and eliminated Hezbollah's Mohammed Nasser, calling him commander of a unit responsible for firing from southwestern Lebanon at Israel.
Nasser, killed by an airstrike near the city of Tyre in southern Lebanon, was the one of the most senior Hezbollah commanders to die yet in the conflict, two security sources in Lebanon said.
The sources in Lebanon said Nasser was responsible for a section of Hezbollah's operations at the frontier.
The Israeli military statement said Nasser and Abdallah "served as two of the most significant Hezbollah terrorists in southern Lebanon".
Israeli attacks in Lebanon have killed more than 300 Hezbollah fighters and 87 civilians, according to Reuters tallies.
event_breakdown: Israeli military targeted eliminated Hezbollah commander Mohammed Nasser near city of Tyre in Lebanon

Hezbollah claims to have fired over 200 rockets and 20 drones on Israel's North, both in the Galilee and in the Golan.
Smoke rises above northern Israel, after Hezbollah claimed it launched more than 200 rockets targeting Israeli military positions in northern Israel July 4, 2024.
This attack was in response to Israel's assassination on Wednesday of Muhammad Neaman Naser, a Hezbollah commander of the Aziz unit on the southern front of Hezbollah.
He was viewed as one of the two most senior commanders killed so far in this war.

title: 1 killed , 7 injured in Israeli airstrikes in S . Lebanon - Xinhua
message:
BEIRUT, July 4 (Xinhua) -- A Hezbollah member was killed, and seven civilians were injured on Thursday in Israeli airstrikes and artillery shelling in southern Lebanon, Lebanese military sources told Xinhua.
The sources noted that the Hezbollah member was killed, and three civilians were injured in an Israeli raid targeting a house in the village of Houla.
The sources indicated that the Israeli bombing destroyed 17 homes, damaged 35 others, and led to nine fires in the border area.
Meanwhile, Hezbollah announced that it attacked several Israeli military sites in retaliation for Israel's assassination of its senior military commander, Mohammad Naameh Nasser, a day earlier.
The level of tension between Hezbollah and the Israeli army has escalated recently, as the Israeli military announced "its approval of operational plans for an attack on Lebanon."

title: Hezbollah fires rockets at Israeli positions after commander killed - World
message:
BEIRUT: Hezbollah said it fired more than 100 rockets at Israeli positions on Wednesday in retaliation for a strike that killed a senior commander in Lebanon, the movement’s second such loss in recent weeks.
The source close to Hezbollah said Nasser had the same rank as Taleb Abdallah, a commander killed in an Israeli strike last month who was described by a Lebanese military source at the time as the “most important” Hezbollah commander killed to date.
That strike prompted Hezbollah to intensify its attacks on Israeli targets, firing barrages of rockets across the border in the days that followed.
A second source close to Hezbollah, also requesting anonymity, said Nasser was the third senior Hezbollah commander to be killed in almost nine months of hostilities.
In January, a security source said an Israeli strike killed Wissam Hassan Tawil, another top commander from the group.

title: Senior Hezbollah commander killed in Israeli strike in Lebanon
message:
A senior Hezbollah commander was killed on Wednesday, July 3, in an Israeli airstrike in the Hosh area of Tyre, Lebanon amid increased tensions between the two sides.
The 59-year-old Mohammad Naameh Nasser, also known as Haj Abu Naameh, was the third most senior Hezbollah commander killed by Israel since the outbreak of cross-border clashes in October 2023.
Israeli airstrikes killed the commander of Hezbollah’s Nasr Unit, Taleb Sami Abdallah, on June 12 and commander, Wissam Al-Tawil who is also known as Jawas was deputy head of the elite Rawdan force of Hezbollah on January 8.
Several hours after the strike, the Israeli Defense Forces (IDF) confirmed that it had killed Nasser, describing him as the head of a unit responsible for firing into Israel from southwest Lebanon.
In Israel, at least 21 people, including 10 civilians, have been killed in Israel due to Hezbollah’s rocket fire and other attacks on civilian areas, Al Jazeera reported.

title: Hezbollah strikes Israeli military sites with barrage of missiles after top commander assassination
message:
Lebanon’s Hezbollah has struck a number of Israeli military sites with more than 200 missiles and drones in retaliation for the regime’s assassination of a top commander of the popular resistance movement in the country’s south.
Since early October, Hezbollah and Israel have been involved in a series of deadly clashes.
Hezbollah has vowed to maintain its retaliatory strikes as long as the Israeli regime continues its Gaza war, which has killed 37,925 people and injured 87,141 so far.
Hezbollah officials have repeatedly said they do not want a war with Israel, but if it happens they are ready.
Nasrallah also said Hezbollah would attack any other country in the region that assisted Israel in the war effort, citing Cyprus, which has hosted Israeli forces for training.

title: Hezbollah fires over 200 rockets into Israel after killing of senior commander
message:
BEIRUT (AP) — The Lebanese Hezbollah group says it’s launched over 200 rockets at several military bases in Israel in retaliation for a strike that killed one of its senior commanders.
The attack by the Iran-backed militant group on Thursday was one of the largest in the monthslong conflict along the Lebanon-Israel border, with tensions boiling in recent weeks.
It acknowledged on Wednesday that it killed Mohammad Naameh Nasser, who headed one of Hezbollah’s three regional divisions in southern Lebanon, a day earlier.
Hours later, Hezbollah launched scores of Katyusha rockets and Falaq rockets with heavy warheads into northern Israel and the Israeli-annexed Golan Heights, followed by more rockets on Thursday.

title: Fear of war between Israel and Hezbollah grows after Israeli strike kills its commander in Lebanon – Ya Libnan
message:
Beirut- Fear of a possible full-scale war between Israel and the Hamas-allied militant group Hezbollah in Lebanon was stoked Thursday after an Israeli airstrike killed a senior Hezbollah commander.
Israel said the commander it killed Wednesday, Mohammad Naameh Nasser, was responsible for firing rockets into Israel.
Hezbollah has stepped up its attacks since Israel, which shares its northern border with Lebanon, launched the war in Gaza in response to Hamas’ Oct. 7 terrorist attack.
The Israel Defense Forces said it intercepted drones and other projectiles fired from southern Lebanon on Thursday and that some of the falling debris caused fires on the ground.
The clashes have also sparked an exodus, forcing tens of thousands of people in both northern Israel and southern Lebanon to flee their homes across the border region.

title: 100 rockets against Israel –
message:
Hezbollah announced it fired “100 Katyusha rockets” at two Israeli positions after a senior commander of the pro-Iranian Shiite group was killed in an Israeli military (IDF) attack in southern Lebanon.
“As part of the response to the enemy’s attack and assassination” in the southern coastal city of Tyre, Hezbollah fighters attacked two Israeli positions on the annexed Golan Heights “with 100 Katyusha rockets,” the Lebanese Party of God said in a statement.
The killing of Hezbollah commander Mohammad Nehma Nasser “will not make the resistance retreat, nor weaken its will and resolve to continue to confront the occupation (Israel), nor will it reduce the pressure on the northern front,” said Hassan Fadlallah, a member of the pro-Iranian Shiite party, at a ceremony organized by the Lebanese group in its stronghold in the southern suburbs of Beirut.
On the contrary, Israel will receive a “punitive response for its crime, so that it understands that the resistance is capable of driving out its army.”Earlier, Hezbollah confirmed the killing of commander Nasser in an attack by the Israel Defense Forces (IDF).
This brings to 358 the number of militants of the Islamist group killed by the IDF in Lebanon and Syria since the clashes between the Israeli army and Hezbollah fighters began after the October 7 attack by Hamas on the Jewish state.

title: Hezbollah fires over 200 rockets into Israel after killing of senior commander
message:
BEIRUT (AP) — The Lebanese Hezbollah group says it’s launched over 200 rockets at several military bases in Israel in retaliation for a strike that killed one of its senior commanders.
The attack by the Iran-backed militant group on Thursday was one of the largest in the monthslong conflict along the Lebanon-Israel border, with tensions boiling in recent weeks.
It acknowledged on Wednesday that it killed Mohammad Naameh Nasser, who headed one of Hezbollah’s three regional divisions in southern Lebanon, a day earlier.
Hours later, Hezbollah launched scores of Katyusha rockets and Falaq rockets with heavy warheads into northern Israel and the Israeli-annexed Golan Heights, followed by more rockets on Thursday.

title: Migrant visas : Leaving war - torn Ukraine was hard , then this AI worker tried Australia
message:
A few days before Russia declared war in early 2022, 18-year-old Ukrainian software engineer Danyil Poprotskyi accepted a job helping Australian entrepreneur Tom Hamer with a coding project that would form the basis of one of Australia’s current hottest artificial intelligence start-ups, Marqo.
“One day I was woken up by an explosion.
That day was pretty rough … I was hiding in the shelter for a few hours hearing constant bombing and I realised it was probably time to try to leave the country.
It was terrifying,” Poprotskyi says.
event_breakdown:
Russia Declares War on Ukraine
An 18-year-old Ukrainian software engineer, Danyil Poprotskyi, accepted a job in Australia in February 2022. A few days before Russia declared war on Ukraine on February 24, 2022, Poprotskyi received a job offer from an Australian entrepreneur. Marqo, an artificial intelligence start-up founded by Hamer, was looking to hire Poprotskyi to work on a coding project.

Russia Declares War on Ukraine
Russia declared war on Ukraine on February 24, 2022. The invasion was a surprise to many, including Poprotskyi, who was working on the project in Australia at the time. Poprotskyi recalls the day vividly, saying he was woken up to the sound of an explosion. The 18-year-old spent the night hiding in a bomb shelter and experienced non-stop bombing.

Poprotskyi realized that it was time to try to leave the country, saying that he felt the "treachery of the situation." The experience was "terrifying," and Poprotskyi was scared for his life.

Poprotskyi has since relocated to Australia and is currently working as a software engineer for Marqo.
Russia Declares War on Ukraine
Poprotskyi's story highlights the uncertainty and danger that many Ukrainians face as a result of the Russian invasion.

2. Manchuria, China - On August 8, 1945, the Soviet Union declared war on Japan and stormed Japanese-held Manchuria with 1.6 million troops. This attack was the catalyst for Japan's surrender, which took place on August 15.
3. The Oval Office - On October 25, 1945, the "father of the atomic bomb" met with President Harry Truman in the Oval Office of the White House. The purpose of the meeting was to discuss the atomic bomb and its role in the end of World War II.

title: Slovakia reclassifies PM shooting as terror attack
message:
(You can now subscribe to our(You can now subscribe to our Economic Times WhatsApp channelBratislava: Slovak authorities have reclassified the assassination attempt on Prime Minister Robert Fico and are investigating it as a terror attack, not as attempted murder, a spokeswoman said on Thursday.Fico is recovering from serious injuries he suffered when a gunman shot him four times from close range after an off-site government meeting in central Slovakia on May 15.The gunman, identified by Slovak media as 71-year-old poet Juraj Cintula, was charged with premeditated attempted murder and remanded in custody.
"It has been reclassified," Zuzana Drobova, a spokeswoman for the general prosecutor's office, told AFP.
"We let the suspect know today that it is now classified as a particularly serious crime of terror attack," she added without giving further details.The 59-year-old Fico leads a three-party governing coalition of his centrist populist Smer-SD party, the centrist Hlas and the far-right SNS.He underwent two lengthy surgeries in a hospital in the central Slovak city of Banska Bystrica and was transferred for home treatment to the capital Bratislava on May 31.

title: Slovakia reclassifies PM shooting as terror attack
message:
Slovak authorities have reclassified the assassination attempt on Prime Minister Robert Fico and are investigating it as a terror attack, not as attempted murder, a spokeswoman said.
The gunman, identified by Slovak media as 71-year-old poet Juraj Cintula, was charged with premeditated attempted murder and remanded in custody.
"We let the suspect know today that it is now classified as a particularly serious crime of terror attack," she added without giving further details.
He underwent two lengthy surgeries in a hospital in the central Slovak city of Banska Bystrica and was transferred for home treatment to the capital Bratislava on 31 May.

title: Russian missiles and drones strike eastern Ukraine Dnipro in a daylight attack that kills 5
message:
(You can now subscribe to our(You can now subscribe to our Economic Times WhatsApp channelA Russian missile and drone attack on the eastern Ukrainian city of Dnipro on Wednesday killed five civilians and injured 47 others, including a 14-year-old girl, authorities said.Blasts blew out some windows of a shopping mall, raining shards onto the street, photos published by local officials showed.
Mayor Borys Filatov said the daytime attack also shattered windows in two schools and three kindergartens.
Debris struck the intensive care unit of a children's hospital, and a fire broke out in another hospital.A video posted on social media by President Volodymyr Zelenskyy showed a missile with a fiery trail streaking over buildings in Ukraine 's fourth-largest city, and debris flying into the air from its impact.The war, now in its third year since Russia invaded its neighbor, has killed more than 10,000 civilians and wounded around 20,000 others, the United Nations says.In the Kharkiv region in the northeast, Russian shelling struck a village council building, killing one person and injuring two others, regional head Oleh Suniehubov said.Elsewhere in the region, a Russian glide bomb struck a residential building in the village of Ruska Lozova, injuring at least two people.
Others could be trapped under rubble, Syniehubov said.Also Wednesday, Ukraine received $2.2 billion from the International Monetary Fund under an ongoing credit facility, Prime Minister Denys Shmyhal announced.The credit program foresees the disbursement of $16 billion, but Ukraine must pass IMF reviews of its progress on key economic and fiscal benchmarks before each part is released.The latest funds will be used for welfare payments and the salaries of doctors and teachers, among other things, Shmyhal said.
event_breakdown:
At least five civilians killed, 47 injured in the Russian missile and drone attack on Dnipro in Ukraine on Wednesday.
Russia shelling hits a village council building in the Kharkiv region, one person is dead and two others are injured.
Russia uses a glide bomb to hit a residential building in Ruska Lozova, two people are injured and residents might be under the rubble.

message:
Russia's defence said it fired Iskander-M missiles at an air base near the central Ukrainian city of Myrgorod, around 150 kilometres from the Russian border.
"As a result of the Russian strike, five operational SU-27 multirole fighters were destroyed, and two that were under repair were damaged," it said in a statement on Telegram.
Russian and Ukrainian military bloggers previously reported the strike on Monday.
But Ukrainian military bloggers and analysts said Kyiv had suffered equipment losses in Myrgorod, with some angry at commanders for parking the planes in the open without sufficient protection.
But recent strikes on Ukrainian airfields have raised questions about Kyiv's ability to protect the multi-million-dollar planes from Russian fire.

title: Senate To Probe Ex - Service Chiefs Over Alleged Fund Diversion
message:
The Senate has backed the Nigerian military’s efforts to stop terrorists and curtail the recent scourge of suicide bombing.
The Senate also asked its relevant committees to support the military in examining the alleged diversion of funds by former service chiefs to construct educational institutions in their respective villages.
Amid these deliberations, the Senate identified three major hot spots in Borno State where Boko Haram fighters are active.
The Senate, led by Senator Mohammed Ali Ndume, who hails from Borno State, put forward suggestions to address the ongoing insurgency.
Senator Akpabio, who presided over the session, attributed the recent suicide bombings in Borno State to a failure of intelligence.

title: Fourth Suspect in Desert Hot Springs Hotel Stabbing Case Pleads Guilty
message:
The last of four suspects in a stabbing at a Desert Hot Springs hotel pleaded guilty Wednesday to multiple charges.
Jaime Eduardo Reynaga, 39, pleaded guilty to assault causing great bodily injury and first-degree burglary Wednesday at the Larson Justice Center in Indio.
Three other men charged in the case, 30-year-old Jose Luis Garcia, 32-year-old Moises Mazariegos and 30-year-old Anthony Rene Ayala, previously pleaded guilty to the same charges.
The stabbing occurred around 11 p.m. April 15, 2021, at a hotel in the 11000 block of Palm Drive, according to the Desert Hot Springs Police Department.
Ayala has two robbery convictions, Garcia has convictions for burglary and attempted robbery, and Reynaga and Mazariegos have convictions for burglary and robbery.

title: Al - Burhan restates rejection of negotiations with RSF
message:
General Abdel Fattah al-Burhan, the Commander-in-Chief of the Sudan Armed Forces (SAF), reiterated his repudiation of engagement in any negotiations that undermines the dignity of the armed forces or fails to meet the aspirations of the Sudanese people.
While addressing his troops, Al-Burhan reaffirmed his stance against negotiating with the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) who have been fighting with the SAF since 15 April 2023.
“We are committed to this battle until we achieve victory and that is all there is to it,” he asserted.
Al-Burhan cited that he is not opposed to negotiations in principle.
“We will not go to negotiations if we are forced into them and we will not negotiate while the enemy still occupies our homes and loots our wealth,” he declared.
event_breakdown:
Target Event: Sudan Sovereignty Challenged by RSF
Report: The Commander-in-Chief of the Sudan Armed Forces (SAF), General Abdel Fattah al-Burhan, repudiated engagement in any negotiations that undermines the dignity of the armed forces or fails to meet the aspirations of the Sudanese people. The reiteration came during a speech addressing troops, in which al-Burhan reaffirmed his stance against negotiating with the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) who have been fighting with the SAF since 15 April 2023. He also cited his readiness for victory against the RSF and refusal to engage in negotiations under his principle.

title: Saudi SAMI , Turkish firms establish new defense collaborations
message:
In a statement, SAMI said it agreed with Türkiye's drone maker Baykar to "establish manufacturing capabilities" and develop systems for Baykar's unmanned aerial vehicles in Saudi Arabia.
It also agreed with Turkish aerospace and defense company Aselsan to explore opportunities for developing defense electronics technologies in the kingdom.
Last year, Saudi Arabia agreed to buy drones from Baykar, the biggest defense contract in Türkiye's history.
In a sign of mending ties, President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan visited Saudi Arabia in April 2022, and Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman (MBS) traveled to Türkiye in June of the same year.

title: Iraqi armed groups say ready to fight Israel if Lebanon war breaks out
message:
As war rages in Gaza and threatens to spread to Lebanon, Iraqi militant groups warn they are ready to enter the fray against Israel and the United States.
The alliance includes Lebanon's Hezbollah and Yemen's Houthi rebels, who have attacked Israel and Israeli-linked shipping, but also armed groups in Syria and Iraq.
On Sunday, the so-called Coordination of the Iraqi Resistance issued further threats against Israel and Israel's top ally the United States.
In late January, a drone strike launched by Iraqi armed groups killed three U.S. soldiers in a base just across the border in Jordan and provoked an armed response.
Iraq specialist Tamer Badawi said the importance of Iraqi groups' "coordinated attacks" carried out with the Houthis "lies in their symbolism".

title: Ft . Eisenhower announces new Garrison Commander during ceremony
message:
AUGUSTA, Ga. (WRDW/WAGT) - Fort Eisenhower announced a new Garrison Commander during a Change of Command ceremony on Wednesday.
Colonel Reginald Evans, relinquished his command to the incoming Fort Eisenhower Garrison Commander, Colonel Anthony Kazor.
Outgoing Garrison Commander Evans has been with the army since 1999.
Evans’ awards and decorations include: The Bronze Star Medal with (3OLC), Defense Meritorious Service Medal with (1OLC), Meritorious Service Medal with (2OLC), Army Commendation Medal with (4OLC), Army Achievement Medal, Joint Meritorious Unit Award, Meritorious Unit Citation Medal with (2OLC), National Defense Service Medal, Afghanistan Campaign Medal, Iraq Campaign Medal, Global War on Terrorism Expeditionary Medal, and Global War on Terrorism Service Medal.
William G. Kidd, SES, Director, Installation Management Command and Training spoke during the ceremony, along with Colonel Evans and Colonel Kazor.
event_breakdown:
Fort Eisenhower Change of Command Ceremony
Fort Eisenhower, Augusta, Georgia
On August 11, 2022, Fort Eisenhower announced a new Garrison Commander during a Change of Command ceremony, with Outgoing Garrison Commander Colonel Reginald Evans relinquishing his command to the incoming Fort Eisenhower Garrison Commander, Colonel Anthony Kazor. Colonel Evans has been with the Army since 1999 and has held various commands and leadership positions.

title: A militia attack on a Congo gold mine kills 6 Chinese miners and 2 Congolese soldiers
message:
A militia attack on a gold mine in northeastern Congo has killed six Chinese miners and two Congolese soldiers, the latest attack as violence worsens in the resource-rich regionGOMA, Congo -- A militia attack on a gold mine in northeastern Congo killed six Chinese miners and two Congolese soldiers, a civil society group said Thursday, the latest assault as violence worsens in the resource-rich region.
A militia known as the Cooperative for the Development of the Congo, or CODECO, claimed responsibility for the attack.
They attackers killed six Chinese miners and two Congolese troops, he added, and abducted two other miners, whose whereabouts remain unknown.
CODECO and the Zaire Militia are involved in a complex conflict, mixing economic ambitions and power struggles.
The Zaire Militia, a dissident faction of CODECO, fiercely opposes its former allies.

title: Poland seeks border guard help from Germany , Greece , Finland
message:
Poland seeks border guard help from Germany, Greece, FinlandWorld World Poland seeks border guard help from Germany, Greece, FinlandGreece is extending its fencing on its border with TurkeyFollow on Published On: Thu, 04 Jul 2024 20:36:15 PKTWARSAW (Reuters) - Poland hopes to bring in border guards and police from Finland, Germany and Greece to help patrol its frontier with Belarus, a senior official said on Thursday, amid mounting concerns over migration pressures from the east into Europe.
"Preparations are underway and these are countries that are very experienced in border protection.
The border between Poland and Belarus has become a flashpoint as Western officials accuse the government in Minsk of using migrants it brings from in from outside of Europe as "hybrid warfare".
Officials in Poland and Finland have warned in recent months that the number of people trying to cross via Belarus or Russia could rise significantly in the near term.
Greece is extending its fencing on its border with Turkey, while Finland seeks to close a new migrant route via Russia to Europe by deploying more border guard patrols, drones and electronic detectors and by building fences.

The group said its latest attack, which followed over 100 rockets fired the previous day, came in response to Israel's killing of a senior Hezbollah commander in south Lebanon.

His death came after an Israeli strike in June killed Taleb Abdallah, who headed another sector.

This retaliation came in response to the killing of Mohammad Naameh Nasser, a senior Hezbollah commander, by Israeli forces.
The Iran-backed Hezbollah group claimed responsibility for the massive barrage, marking one of the largest attacks in the months-long conflict along the Lebanon-Israel border.

(Photo: Reuters)SEOUL - A South Korean court sentenced a man to 15 years in prison for stabbing the leader of the main opposition party, which was one of the most high-profile cases of political violence in the country in recent years.
Prosecutors had sought a 20-year prison term for Kim on charges of attempted murder and violation of the election law.
Kim stabbed Democratic Party leader Lee Jae-myung in the neck in January, just months before South Korea was to hold general elections.
Lee underwent surgery, survived the attack and went on to lead the party to a landslide victory in the April parliamentary vote.

title: Oslo Pride shooter handed maximum sentence
message:
- Advertisement -Oslo, Norway—The gunman who killed two people at Oslo’s 2022 Pride festival was handed decades behind bars Thursday over the attack that the court said aimed to “instill fear in LGBTQ people”.
Zaniar Matapour, who pledged allegiance to the Islamic State group, was found guilty of opening fire on June 25, 2022 outside two bars in central Oslo, including a famous gay club, just hours before the Pride Parade.
Norway handed the 45-year-old Norwegian of Iranian origin the maximum penalty of 30 years behind bars—with possible extensions—for committing an “aggravated act of terror.”“The attack undoubtedly targeted gay people,” the Oslo court said in its verdict.
“The court deems that Matapour fully understood what he was doing before and during the attack,” the verdict said, finding that he deliberately targeted the LGBTQ community.
Oslo’s Pride festival, scheduled to take place a few hours after the shooting, was eventually cancelled.
event_breakdown: Oslo Pride parade shooting (2022)

title: Russian air defences downed over 42 , 000 targets since start of Ukraine conflict | Central India Premier English Daily
message:
Moscow, July 5 (UNI) The Russian air defence forces and air defence means have destroyed more than 42,000 air targets, including over 550 aircraft and 27,000 drones, since the beginning of Russia’s special military operation in Ukraine, Lt. Gen. Andrei Semenov, commander of the air and missile defence forces and deputy commander-in-chief of the Russian Aerospace Forces, told journalists.
“In total, more than 42,000 air targets have been destroyed by the air defence forces during the special military operation.
This includes more than 550 planes, over 180 helicopters, and more than 27,000 UAVs [unmanned aerial vehicles],” Semenov said.
The commander added that about a third of Ukraine’s manned aircraft have been destroyed by short-range air defence systems from forward echelons.
In total, these systems have destroyed a third of the manned aviation of the Ukrainian armed forces,” the general said.

title: Turkish police catch 45 Daesh - linked suspects in 16 cities
message:
Interior Minister Ali Yerlikaya on Friday said Turkish authorities have captured a total of 45 suspects linked to the Daesh terrorist group in nationwide raids.
Türkiye has been rounding up Daesh-linked suspects in ramped-up operations since the terrorist group attacked an Italian church in Istanbul in late January, killing one man during Sunday Mass.
The National Intelligence Organization (MIT) thwarted the terrorist group's efforts for recruitment, obtaining funds and logistics support after its latest operation in the aftermath of the church shooting.
Daesh members have not previously targeted places of worship on Turkish soil.
In December last year, Turkish intelligence captured a top Daesh terrorist in charge of the terrorist group’s finances in the Damascus region in an operation in Türkiye’s southern Mersin province.

message:
A Ukrainian drone assault targeted a gunpowder factory in western Russia, a Kyiv security source said Thursday, in the latest strike aiming to dent Russia's military logistics.
The Ukrainian defence source said the site produced ammunition and gunpowder for small arms and had been targeted by drones in January and November.
The attack comes as Russia has been launching a systematic strike campaign targeting Ukrainian energy infrastructure, causing lasting damage to critical facilities and spurring the introduction of scheduled outages.
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has appealed to Kyiv's allies to supply more air defence systems to thwart Russian missile and drone barrages.
Zelensky has said systematic Russian attacks on energy facilities have halved Ukrainian electricity production compared to one year ago.

title: Pakistan : 3 killed , 8 injured in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa blast
message:
Islamabad, July 5 : At least three people were killed and eight others injured when a blast went off in Pakistan's northwest Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province on Friday, the police said.
The blast took place on a bridge in the Takht-i-Bahi area of Mardan district of the province, killing three people while injuring eight others, including policemen, District Police Officer Mardan Zahoor Babar Afridi told the media.
Rescue teams, police, and security forces immediately reached the site following the blast and shifted the injured to a nearby hospital.
The area has been cordoned off while a search operation is underway to arrest the culprits.
Earlier on Thursday, five people, including a former member of the Senate, were killed in an explosion in Bajaur district of the province.

title: What is the U . S . Indo - Pacific Command ( INDOPACOM )?
message:
U.S. Indo-Pacific Command, or INDOPACOM, is one of the U.S. Department of Defense’s eleven unified combatant commands that together span the globe.
Forces Japan, U.S. Special Operations Command Pacific, U.S. Pacific Fleet, U.S. Marine Forces Pacific, U.S. Pacific Air Forces, and U.S. Army Pacific.
It is the result of a merger between three commands–Far East Command, Pacific Command and Alaskan Command–which were established after World War II in 1947.
By 1957, Pacific Command saw a major expansion and strategic reorientation of its AOR, absorbing the Far East Command and most of the Alaskan Command.
In 2018, Pacific Command was rebranded to Indo-Pacific Command, or INDOPACOM, as it is known today.
event_breakdown: U.S. Indo-Pacific Command (INDOPACOM) was established in 2018. It encompasses nearly 50% of the Earth’s surface. It encompasses three distinct American defense commands: the Pacific Command, the Alaskan Command, & the Hawaii-based U.S. Pacific Command. The merged command has an area of responsibility that stretches from the west coast of the U.S. to the west coast of India.

title: Oslo Pride shooter handed maximum sentence - Newspaper
message:
OSLO: The gunman who killed two people at Oslo’s 2022 Pride festival was handed decades behind bars on Thursday over the attack that the court said aimed to “instill fear in LGBTQ people”.
Zaniar Matapour, who pledged allegiance to the the militant Islamic State group, was found guilty of opening fire on June 25, 2022 outside two bars in central Oslo, including a famous gay club, just hours before the Pride Parade.
Norway handed the 45-year-old Norwegian of Iranian origin the maximum penalty of 30 years behind bars — with possible extensions — for committing an “aggravated act of terror.” “The attack undoubtedly targeted gay people,” the Oslo court said in its verdict.
Matapour, who was restrained by passersby after the shooting, has never revealed his motives.
Psychiatric experts have been divided over his mental health, and thereby his legal responsibility, as the accused has previously been diagnosed with paranoid schizophrenia.

title: Institute develops powerful explosive
message:
Institute develops powerful explosiveBOLSTERING DEFENSE: The explosive is 40 percent more powerful than those in use and could be deployed for Hsiung Feng II and III missiles, a government source saidBy Lo Tien-pin and Jake Chung / Staff reporter, with staff writerThe Chungshan Institute of Science and Technology has developed a polycyclic nitroamine explosive, commonly known as CL-20, which is the most powerful non-nuclear explosive known, a government source said yesterday on condition of anonymity.
The institute has significantly improved explosive and rocket propellant research and development in recent years, the source said.
The explosive is 40 percent more powerful than those currently used and could be deployed for Hsiung Feng II (“Brave Wind” II, HF-II) and HF-III missiles, the source said.
Despite difficulties in mass production, CL-20 has seen some minor uses within the US and China, and has also been used in the Russia-Ukraine war, the source said.
In tandem with domestic companies, the institute has researched and built a 1,136-liter mixer from the ground up, further enhancing the autonomy of Taiwan’s national defense sector.

title: U . S . Veterans Spend Independence Day Diving With Sharks Near Jupiter | Vero Patriot
message:
However you spent your Independence Day, it's likely it wasn't diving with sharks...but that's how a group of U.S. veterans spent their July 4th.
Many of those who took part in the Freedom Dive near Jupiter are Purple Heart recipients, including Army Veteran Chris Short who lost part of his leg in combat in Afghanistan.
But with veterans, especially folks who've been in combat, it's just we have a unique bond.
Other veterans tell CBS 12 News that they were lucky to have spent such a special day with special people.
The dive was free and sponsored by a number of local businesses and the Wounded Veterans Relief Fund.
event_breakdown: Freedom Dive near Jupiter

title: Russia shamed as  binge drinking  commander blamed for huge drone attack by Ukraine | World | News
message:
Ukrainian sea drones attack Russian ships in CrimeaA Russian commander was allegedly binge drinking during a drone attack on naval vessels in Novorossiysk port.
Ukraine, however, has now started to target Russian ships in Novorossiysk, using its Magura V5 maritime drones.
On Wednesday, the city's Mayor Andrey Kravchenko confirmed the port had come under attack from "unmanned boats".
In a post to this Telegram channel, Battle Sailor praised those responsible for foiling the attack, hailing them as the "pride of the Russian fleet".
Ukraine has succeeded in inflicting devastating damage on Putin's Black Sea Fleet, despite having no navy of its own to speak of.

title: Accused of murdering of a Nukhba terrorist ? We got to the south , but army was not there
message:
S., one of the two suspects "in the murder of a Nukhba terrorist," talks about the case, the arrest and the investigation against him.
Under house arrest at his 73-year-old grandfather, S. told Ynet, "Being accused of murdering a Nukhba terrorist.
Almost everyone in Israel, including myself, went down south to fight in the Gaza surrounding communities, while the army was not there."
There were four other fighters from an elite unit, who unfortunately were killed during the battles against the terrorists.
My friend got shot in the shoulder, but he continued to fight."

title: Released Gaza detainees allege torture by Israel amid war
message:
Released Gaza detainees allege torture by Israel amid warGAZA STRIPBlindfolded, beaten and sometimes bitten by dogs, Gazans released from Israeli prisons allege being tortured amid the Israel-Hamas war, which rights groups say has worsened conditions for detainees.
AFP interviewed some of the 50 prisoners taken to Kamal Adwan Hospital in the Gaza Strip after their release by Israel on June 11.
In April, the Haaretz newspaper quoted a letter to Israel's defence ministry from a doctor at an Israeli army camp.
In May, the Israeli army said it "rejects outright" allegations in a U.S. media report of stripping, sexually abusing and electrocuting detainees during interrogations.
Hundreds are awaiting indictment, the attorney added, while more than 1,500 have been released and returned to Gaza.

title: Released Gaza detainees allege torture by Israel amid war
message:
July 5, 2024 — Jerusalem (AFP)Blindfolded, beaten and sometimes bitten by dogs, Gazans released from Israeli prisons allege being tortured amid the Israel-Hamas war, which rights groups say has worsened conditions for detainees.
AFP interviewed some of the 50 prisoners taken to Kamal Adwan Hospital in the Gaza Strip after their release by Israel on June 11.
In April, the Haaretz newspaper quoted a letter to Israel's defence ministry from a doctor at an Israeli army camp.
In May, the Israeli army said it "rejects outright" allegations in a US media report of stripping, sexually abusing and electrocuting detainees during interrogations.
Hundreds are awaiting indictment, the attorney added, while more than 1,500 have been released and returned to Gaza.
